facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 4, 1957, of the Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 173-C of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1957, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 173-C of 1956. C. Arathur, P. C. Mathur and A. N. Goyal, for the Appellants.

facts.text: This appeal was first heard by a Division Bench of three judges, composed of the Chief Justice, Imam and Shah, JJ., on the 19th of February last year.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was first heard by a Division Bench of three judges, companyposed of the Chief Justice, Imam and Shah, JJ., on the 19th of February last year. In the companyrse of the argument, the learned companynsel for the appellant invited the attention of the Court to the decision of a Division Bench of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 .

facts.text: The appellant was an upper Division Clerk in the office of the Chief Commissioner of Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was an upper Division Clerk in the office of the Chief Commissioner of Delhi. He had companye to know  1  1959 Supp. 2. S.C.R. 739. Ram Narain, who is the chief prosecution witness in this case and who is a fireman serving in Delhi Fire Brigade.

facts.text: Ram Narain is a fireman serving in Delhi Fire Brigade.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain, who is the chief prosecution witness in this case and who is a fireman serving in Delhi Fire Brigade. Ram Narain, aforesaid, had for a long time been anxious to obtain a licence for a double-barrelled shotgun.

facts.text: Ram Narain had submitted two applications during the year 1953 for obtaining the licence with the assistance of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain, aforesaid, had for a long time been anxious to obtain a licence for a double-barrelled shotgun. It is alleged that in this companynection he bad sought the assistance of the appellant who had numberhing to do with the issuing of licences for firearms, which is done by the office of the Deputy Commissioner, Delhi.

facts.text: These applications did not produce any results.

anchor.surface_text: the, purpose of obtaining the licence aforesaid, with the assistance of the appellant. These applications did number produce any results. In .1954, he made another attempt in the same direction and approached the appellant to help him.

facts.text: In 1954, Ram Narain approached the appellant who held out hopes of success if paid Rs. 250.

anchor.surface_text: In .1954, he made another attempt in the same direction and approached the appellant to help him. The appellant held out hopes of success in obtaining the licence if he was paid Rs. 250. Ram Narain paid only Rs. 140 and held out a promise to pay the amount after his sisters marriage.

facts.text: Ram Narain paid Rs. 140 to the appellant and promised the rest after his sister's marriage.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant held out hopes of success in obtaining the licence if he was paid Rs. 250. Ram Narain paid only Rs. 140 and held out a promise to pay the amount after his sisters marriage. Thus, the third application for the licence was made in which Rain Narains salary was declared to be Rs. 105 per month.

facts.text: In the third application, Ram Narain's salary was declared as Rs. 105 per month (actual Rs. 85).

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the third application for the licence was made in which Rain Narains salary was declared to be Rs. 105 per month. This third attempt proved successful and Ram Narain was granted the necessary licence.

facts.text: Ram Narain was granted the licence.

anchor.surface_text: This third attempt proved successful and Ram Narain was granted the necessary licence. Before the learned single Judge of the High Court in Delhi, before whom the case came, up on appeal, it was number disputed that the appellant had used his good offices in expediting and furthering the progress of the application in the appropriate department.

facts.text: It was not disputed that the appellant had used his good offices in expediting the application.

anchor.surface_text: Before the learned single Judge of the High Court in Delhi, before whom the case came, up on appeal, it was number disputed that the appellant had used his good offices in expediting and furthering the progress of the application in the appropriate department.

facts.text: Ram Narain's salary was actually Rs. 85 per month, licence cancelled when known.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that eventually the authorities companycerned were appraised of the fact that the salary of Ram Narain was only Rs. 85 per month and that the declaration in the form that his salary was Rs. 105 per month bad been falsely made with a view to get over the difficulty that applications for licences for firearms by Government servants drawing less than Rs. 100 per month would number ordinarily be companysidered.

facts.text: Ram Narain alleged false salary declaration on advice of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: When the authorities came to know- the true facts about Ram Narains status in Government service. his licence was cancelled and he was called upon to show cause why he should number be prosecuted for having made a false statement. Ram Narain made his representation to the authorities and showed cause against the action proposed to be taken against him, alleging that his monthly salary had been falsely declared in the relevant form for application for the firearm on the advice of the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant demanded Rs. 180 for restoring the licence, Ram Narain agreed to pay Rs. 90 in advance.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution story further is that when Ram Narain got into the trouble, as aforesaid, about the false statement in his application form, he again approached the appellant. The appellant demanded another Rs. 180 as a reward for his getting the licence restored. Ultimately, Ram Narain agreed to pay the appellant Rs. 90 in advance and promised to pay the remaining Rs. 90 after the licence had actually been restored to him.

facts.text: On August 5, 1954, Ram Narain handed over Rs. 90 to appellant in the canteen on Alipore Road.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain saw the appellant in the Chief Commissioners office and accompanied him to the canteen run by Kishorilal, who has been examined as Defence Witness 1 This canteen is situated on the Alipore Road near the Chief Commissioners office. There, Sarwan Singh a taxi driver, and Head Constable Gurbachan Singh in plain clothes, who were examined as prosecution witnesses, were present by arrangement. Ram Narain handed over the ninety rupees, which he had been given by the police, to the appellant.

facts.text: Police laid a trap, signal given by Sarwan Singh, Inspector Surendra Pal Singh entered.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Narain handed over the ninety rupees, which he had been given by the police, to the appellant. On the prearranged signal being given by Sarwan Singh, Inspector Surendra Pal Singh Prosecution Witness 16, at once entered the canteen.

facts.text: Appellant attempted to hand over money to Kishorilal, seized by Head Constable Gurbachan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On the prearranged signal being given by Sarwan Singh, Inspector Surendra Pal Singh Prosecution Witness 16, at once entered the canteen. At that time the appellant, suspecting that he was being trapped, attempted to hand over the money received by him from Ram Narain to Kishorilal, the proprietor of the canteen The head companystable Gurbacban Singh, however, seized the accused and prevented him from handing over the currency numberes to Kishorilal.

facts.text: First Information Report drawn up at Civil Lines Police Station at 2:30 p.m. on August 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That is the story which was recited in the First Information Report drawn up in the. Civil Lines Police Station at 2-30 P.m. that very day, August 5, 1954. After investigation by a companypetent police officer tinder permission from the Magistrate, the appellant was placed on his trial before Shri Jawala.

facts.text: Appellant tried before Special Judge Shri Jawala Dass, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: After investigation by a companypetent police officer tinder permission from the Magistrate, the appellant was placed on his trial before Shri Jawala. Dass, Special Judge Delhi.

facts.text: Charge framed against Dhaneshwar Narain u/s 161 IPC or s.5(1)(d) punishable u/s 5(2) Prevention of Corruption Act for obtaining Rs.90 on August 5, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: He framed the following charge against him. I, Jawala Dass, Special Judge, Delhi, hereby charge you  Dhaneshwar Narain  son of Babu Lakshmi Narain resident of 21, Todar Mal Lane, New Delhi as follows That you on or about 5th August 1954 in the canteen on 6, Alipore Road, being a public servant employed in the office of the Chief Commissioner, Delhi by companyrupt and illegal moans and by otherwise abusing your position as a public servant obtained for yourself a sum of Rs. 90 from Ram Narain at the aforesaid Canteen for the restoration of his cancelled licence for the double-barrelled gun which had been originally grant to him, by the District Magistrate Delhi and thereby companymitted an offence u s 161 I.P.C. or in the alternative u s 5 1  d  punishable u s 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, which is within my companynizance.

facts.text: Special Judge convicted appellant under s.5(1)(d) punishable under s.5(2) of Prevention of Corruption Act and sentenced to six months rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge came to the companyclusion that the evidence produced by the prosecution brought the charge home to the accused, and that the accused, taking advantage of his own position as an employee in the Chief Commissioners office, and of Ram Narains ignorance and anxiety to get the licence had induced him to part with the money on the pro- mise that he will get his licence restored.

facts.text: Appeal heard by Mr. Justice Falshaw of Punjab High Court, judgment dated February 4, 1957, affirmed conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant preferred an appeal which was heard by Mr. Justice Falshaw of the Punjab High Court. The learned Judge, by his judgment and order dated February 4,1957 substantially affirmed the findings of the learned Special Judge and maintained the order of companyviction and sentence.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave to appeal from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, failing to obtain a certificate from the High Court that his was a fit case for farther appeal to ,his Court, applied for, and obtained from this Court, special leave to appeal from the judgment of the single, Judge of the High Court.

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 6 of 1959 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 6 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1957, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 173-C of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 24, 1961 by SINHA, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: K. Khanna and T. M. Sen, for the Respondents. 1961. August 24. ,The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA, C. J.-This appeal was first heard by a Division Bench of three judges, companyposed of the Chief Justice, Imam and Shah, JJ., on the 19th of February last year.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the February 4, 1957, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 173-C of 1956.

The appellant, failing to obtain a certificate from the High Court that his was a fit case for farther appeal to ,his Court, applied for, and obtained from this Court, special leave to appeal from the judgment of the single, Judge of the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant portion of s. 5 of the Act is in these terms Criminal misconduct in discharge of official duty- A public servant is said to commit the offence of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duty-  a   b   c   d if he, by corrupt or illegal means or by otherwise abusing his position as a public servant, obtains for himself or for any other person any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage.

concepts.interpretation: 'In discharge of his duty' is merely nomenclature, not essential ingredient; ingredients for cl.(d): (1) public servant, (2) corrupt/illegal means or abuse position, (3) obtains valuable thing/pecuniary advantage, (4) for self/another. No need for misconduct in discharge of own duty.

issues.text: Whether on the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below, accepting the prosecution story, an offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act has been made out

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court it has been strenuously argued that on the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below, accepting the prosecution story as told by the main prosecution witness Ram Narain, numberoffence under s. 5 1  d  of the Act has been made out. Reliance was placed mainly upon the,

issues.text: Whether the decision in State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal requires reconsideration with respect to the interpretation of s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the argument, the learned counsel for the appellant invited the attention of the Court to the decision of a Division Bench of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 1 . The Bench hearing the case, being of opinion that the decision aforesaid of this Court required reconsideration, referred the case to a larger bench, and that is how it has come before US.

issues.text: Whether it is a necessary element of the offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act that the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharge of his own duty

anchor.surface_text: That case, if correctly decided, certainly supports the appellant, contention, because it has been laid down in that case that in order to attract the operation of s. 5 1 d of the Act it was necessary element of the crime charged that, the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharg -of his own duty, and that if the official favour promised by the public servant to the giver of the money was number in the hands of the public servant, he could number be said to have misconducted himself in he discharge of his own duty.

issues.text: Whether the words 'in the discharge of his duty' constitute an essential ingredient of the offences described in s.5(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act

anchor.surface_text: The words in the discharge of his duty do number constitute an essential ingredient of the offence. The mistake in the judgemnt of this Court in the aforsaid ruling in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 1 shas arisen from reading those words. which are part merely of the nomenclature of the offence created by the Statute, whose ingredients are set out in sub-claused 1 to d that follow as descriptive of an essential and additional ingriedent of each of the types of offence in the four sub-clauses.

issues.text: Whether an offence under s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act requires the element of gratification as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act as required under s.161 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The necessary ingredient of an offence under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, is the clause as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act or for showing or forbearing to show in the exercise of his official functions favour or disfavour to any person or for rendering or attempting to render any service or dis-service to any person with the Central or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State or wiht any public servent.But it need number be there in order to bring an offence under s.5 of the Act home to the accused .

arguments.claim: No offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act has been made out on the facts, as the public servant did not misconduct himself in the discharge of his own duty since issuing firearm licences was not part of his duties

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court it has been strenuously argued that on the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below, accepting the prosecution story as told by the main prosecution witness Ram Narain, no offence under s. 5 1  d  of the Act has been made out. Reliance was placed mainly upon the decision of the Division Bench of this Court in State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 . That case, if correctly decided, certainly supports the appellant's contention, because it has been laid down in that case that in order to attract the operation of s. 5 1 d of the Act it was necessary element of the crime charged that, the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharg -of his own duty

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Act. The ratio of the decision is companytained in the following paragraph of the judgment in that case The offence under this provision companysists

arguments.court_reasoning: 'In the discharge of his duty' is merely part of the section's nomenclature, not an essential ingredient; the offence under cl.(d) requires only: (1) public servant, (2) corrupt/illegal means or abuse of position, (3) obtains valuable thing/pecuniary advantage for self/other

arguments.claim: The case does not fall within s.161 IPC because the appellant did not tell Ram Narain that the money was wanted for someone in a position to issue the licence; convicted under s.5(1)(d) PC Act as evidence brings charge home

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge came to the conclusion that the evidence produced by the prosecution brought the charge home to the accused, and that the accused, taking advantage of his own position as an employee in the Chief Commissioners office, and of Ram Narains ignorance and anxiety to get the licence had induced him to part with the money on the pro- mise that he will get his licence restored. He also found that at the time of making this demand the appellant had number told Ram Narain

arguments.claim: The decision in State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal requires reconsideration

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the argument, the learned counsel for the appellant invited the attention of the Court to the decision of a Division Bench of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 1 . The Bench hearing the case, being of opinion that the decision aforesaid of this Court required reconsideration, referred the case to a larger bench, and that is how it has come before us.

arguments.claim: The words 'in the discharge of his duty' do not constitute an essential ingredient of the offence under s.5(1); they are merely nomenclature; mistake in Shivji Lal arose from misreading them as descriptive of ingredients

anchor.surface_text: The words in the discharge of his duty do number constitute an essential ingredient of the offence. The mistake in the judgemnt of this Court in the aforsaid ruling in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal 1 shas arisen from reading those words. which are part merely of the nomenclature of the offence created by the Statute, whose ingredients are set out in sub-claused 1 to d that follow as descriptive of an essential and additional ingriedent

arguments.claim: Ingredients of offence under s.5(1)(d) are: (1) public servant, (2) uses corrupt/illegal means or abuses position, (3) thereby obtains valuable thing/pecuniary advantage, (4) for self or other; no requirement of misconduct in discharge of own duty

anchor.surface_text: The ingredients of the particular offence in cl. d of s.5 1 of the ACt are 1 that he should be a public servant 2 that he should use some corrupt or illegal means or otherwise abouse his position as a public servant 3 that he should have thereby obtained a valuable thing or pecuniery advantage and 4 for himself or for any other person.

arguments.claim: Misconduct under s.5(1)(c) (dishonest misappropriation of entrusted property) is not in discharge of duty, analogously showing s.5(1)(d) does not require element of discharge of duty (citing Hori Ram Singh v. Crown)

anchor.surface_text: That misconduct, which has been made criminal by s. 5 of the Act, does number contain the element of discharge of his duty, by public servant, is also made clear by reference to the provisions of cl. c of s. 5 1 . It is well settled that if a public servant dishonestly or fraudulently misappropriates property entrusted to him, he cannot be said to have been doing so in the discharge of his official duty vide the case of Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown

arguments.claim: Offence under s.5 PC Act does not require ingredient of gratification as motive/reward for official act, unlike s.161 IPC which does

anchor.surface_text: The necessary ingredient of an offence under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, is the clause as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act or for showing or forbearing to show in the exercise of his official functions favour or disfavour to any person or for rendering or attempting to render any service or dis-service to any person with the Central or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State or wiht any public servent.But it need number be there in order to bring an offence under s.5 of the Act home to the accused

arguments.claim: Prosecution evidence sufficient to prove charge under s.5(1)(d) PC Act

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge came to the conclusion that the evidence produced by the prosecution brought the charge home to the accused, and that the accused, taking advantage of his own position as an employee in the Chief Commissioners office, and of Ram Narains ignorance and anxiety to get the licence had induced him to part with the money on the pro- mise that he will get his licence restored.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: wide definition in s.5 wiht a view to punish those who holding public office and taking advantage of their official position obtain any valuable thin

arguments.court_reasoning: Facts fit ingredients of s.5(1)(d); appellant abused position to obtain money despite no direct duty over licensing

arguments.claim: s.5 PC Act widens scope beyond IPC offences like s.161 to punish public servants abusing position for valuable things, per legislative intent

anchor.surface_text: That is a new offence which was created by the Act, apart from and in addition to offences under the Indian Penal Code, like those under s.161 etc. The legislature advisedly widened the scope of the crime by giving a very wide definition in s.5 with a view to punish those who holding public office and taking advantage of their official position obtain any valuable thing or pecuniary advantage.

holdings.text: On the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below, accepting the prosecution story, an offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act has been made out.

anchor.surface_text: Before this Court it has been strenuously argued that on the findings of fact arrived at by the courts below, accepting the prosecution story as told by the main prosecution witness Ram Narain, numberoffence under s. 5 1  d  of the Act has been made out. Reliance was placed mainly upon the,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts' factual findings accepted; facts satisfy ingredients of s.5(1)(d) despite no direct duty in licensing; appellant abused position as public servant to obtain money.

holdings.text: The decision in State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal requires reconsideration with respect to the interpretation of s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the argument, the learned counsel for the appellant invited the attention of the Court to the decision of a Division Bench of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 . The Bench hearing the case, being of opinion that the decision aforesaid of this Court required reconsideration, referred the case to a larger bench, and that is how it has come before US.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench referred to larger bench due to doubt on prior interpretation; larger bench provides new reading of statute.

holdings.text: It is not a necessary element of the offence under s.5(1)(d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act that the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharge of his own duty.

anchor.surface_text: That case, if correctly decided, certainly supports the appellant, contention, because it has been laid down in that case that in order to attract the operation of s. 5 1 d of the Act it was necessary element of the crime charged that, the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharg -of his own duty, and that if the official favour promised by the public servant to the giver of the money was number in the hands of the public servant, he could number be said to have misconducted himself in he discharge of his own duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory ingredients do not require connection to own duty; prior case misread section; duty and misconduct are antithetical.

holdings.text: The words 'in the discharge of his duty' do not constitute an essential ingredient of the offences described in s.5(1) of the Prevention of Corruption Act; they are merely part of the nomenclature.

anchor.surface_text: The words in the discharge of his duty do number constitute an essential ingredient of the offence. The mistake in the judgemnt of this Court in the aforsaid ruling in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 shas arisen from reading those words. which are part merely of the nomenclature of the offence created by the Statute, whose ingredients are set out in sub-claused 1 to d that follow as descriptive of an essential and additional ingriedent of each of the types of offence in the four sub-clauses.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Phrase is heading/nomenclature, not ingredient; ingredients explicitly in subclauses (a)-(d); misreading caused error in Shivji Lal.

holdings.text: An offence under s.5(1)(d) read with s.5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act does not require the element of gratification as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act as required under s.161 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary ingredient of an offence under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, is the clause as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act or for showing or forbearing to show in the exercise of his official functions favour or disfavour to any person or for rendering or attempting to render any service or dis-service to any person with the Central or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State or wiht any public servent.But it need number be there in order to bring an offence under s.5 of the Act home to the accused .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 creates new broader offence beyond IPC s.161; no such specific intent required; legislature widened scope to punish abuse of position.

holdings.text: The ingredients of the offence under s.5(1)(d) are: (1) accused is public servant; (2) uses corrupt/illegal means or abuses position as public servant; (3) thereby obtains valuable thing or pecuniary advantage; (4) for himself or any other person.

anchor.surface_text: The ingredients of the particular offence in cl.  d  of s.5  1  of the ACt are 1  that he should be a public servant  2  that he should use some companyrupt or illegal means or otherwise abouse his position as a public servant 3  that he should have thereby obtained a valuable thing or pecuniery advantage and  4  for himself or for any other person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual parsing of clause (d); no additional 'discharge of duty' element; confirmed by analogy to clause (c) and precedents like Hori Ram Singh.

precedents.case_name: State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: Decision requires reconsideration as it holds that for offence under s.5(1)(d) of Prevention of Corruption Act, public servant must misconduct in discharge of his own duty
precedents.cited_holding: The offence under this provision consists of criminal misconduct in the discharge of his duty. In order, therefore, that this offence is committed there should be misconduct by the public servant in the discharge of his duty.

anchor.surface_text: In the course of the argument, the learned counsel for the appellant invited the attention of the Court to the decision of a Division Bench of this Court in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 . The Bench hearing the case, being of opinion that the decision aforesaid of this Court required reconsideration, referred the case to a larger bench, and that is how it has come before US.
These observations dispose of the present appeal and it must be held that there is numbermerit in the companytentions raised in support of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: That case, if correctly decided, certainly supports the appellant, contention, because it has been laid down in that case that in order to attract the operation of s. 5 1 d of the Act it was necessary element of the crime charged that, the public servant should have misconducted himself in the discharg -of his own duty, and that if the official favour promised by the public servant to the giver of the money was number in the hands of the public servant, he could number be said to have misconducted himself in he discharge of his own duty.
These observations dispose of the present appeal and it must be held that there is numbermerit in the companytentions raised in support of the appeal.

edges.explanation: Holding reinterpreting s.5(1)(d) without own duty requirement overrules precedent p1 (Shivji Lal) as noted in c11

anchor.surface_text: The words in the discharge of his duty do number constitute an essential ingredient of the offence. The mistake in the judgemnt of this Court in the aforsaid ruling in the State of Ajmer v. Shivji Lal  1 shas arisen from reading those words. which are part merely of the nomenclature of the offence created by the Statute, whose ingredients are set out in sub-claused 1 to d that follow as descriptive of an essential and additional ingriedent of each of the types of offence in the four sub-clauses.
These observations dispose of the present appeal and it must be held that there is numbermerit in the companytentions raised in support of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The necessary ingredient of an offence under s. 161, Indian Penal Code, is the clause as a motive or reward for doing or forbearing to do any official act or for showing or forbearing to show in the exercise of his official functions favour or disfavour to any person or for rendering or attempting to render any service or dis-service to any person with the Central or any State Government or Parliament or the Legislature of any State or wiht any public servent.But it need number be there in order to bring an offence under s.5 of the Act home to the accused .
These observations dispose of the present appeal and it must be held that there is numbermerit in the companytentions raised in support of the appeal.
